content: not one diagnoal test really?

I think some of the validators and test cases should be switched.
I had a typo in my code (wrote 'Y' instead of 'O')  but all test cases passed since only 'X' wins in the test cases.
If at least one test case had 'O' winning this type of mistakes could be easily spotted.
Maybe you could also add some tests for the case of diagonal line, one could get surprised after submitting with 100% score from tests and getting only 60% from final validation :)
Seeing how most people fail in clashes if they require more than 20 lines, I'd say take out the diagonal and it'll be a good clash.
good idea, but maybe too hard in 15 minutes. I think simple Tic-Tac-Toe (not Extreme) would be ok for clash of code
I just realized something.  I didn't check columns and still passed all the tests.  None of your solutions  make use of winning via columns.

I don't think size of the grid affects the difficulty much except for maybe in reverse mode where you might be trying to hand count them to figure out what the solution is.

I found the problem to be fun and challenging but as others have said it might be beyond the 15 minute requirement.

As for shortest I understand what dolitham is saying but I did work on a shortest solution (got down to 229 in Ruby) and it was fun trying to use all of my learned Ruby tricks.

Final thoughts: To hard for Clash, but I don't know what to do to fix it. Dropping diagonals is probably the right solution.  Or what if you made it instead of finding the longest, you instead search for a whole row, column, or diagonal that is all X's or O's for that player to win.  If you find at least one of each then it's a tie.

I'm afraid most clashers wouldn't be able to get to a functioning result in 15 minutes (can you code yours in <15 minutes ?) but the problem itself is interesting.
Perhaps it would be more realistic if not including the diagonals, though it kinda removes the whole interest of this problem. 

I don't see the purpose of having this as shortest : for such complicated problems, shortest only means "who can write the most unreadable code ?" and it is not an interesting skill to train.
Submitted this to Puzzle but some people thought it suited Clash more, so I'm resubmitting to Clash.

It seems to float in that awkward difficulty region between Puzzle and Clash.  I think it would be much more Clash-like if diagonal lines didn't count, and then it would be OK for Fastest and Shortest.  Omitting diagonals would confuse things for Reverse, but that could be rescued with a good enough example (maybe a 5x5 Checkered but with one cell flipped)

A thing I like about the simplified problem is that players can decide whether they actually want to build a 2D array of the board, or do everything in one pass.
Good points. I don't have an argument for this being shortest. For fastest, I had submitted a version with only 3x3 grids but apparently that was too easy. Maybe I should have only 5x5?

I went with your last suggestion - only whole rows / columns / diagonals count. This reduces the number of diagonals down to 2, and you don't have to check smaller lengths, which should be a good difficulty level for clash.
Cheers, updated.

Yes that's the general consensus before I changed the rules. But I think now with the added rule that winner must make a line that spans the entire length of the grid it's actually easier than normal Tic-Tac-Toe (for which you must search for the longest line in a grid with empty cells in addition to XO). What do you think?
...and I just had this exact Clash twice in a row - once as "fastest" and once as "shortest". Both times, I was the only one to finish it...
Moreover, it's not specified anywhere..

In fact, it is, there is a word "diagonal" in the "Constraints" section, but I also didn't mention it for the first time. Another fact is that one doesn't expect winning condition in that section... I think it would be fine to move that line it upwards and add a test for everything that is required. @theducvu please, can you think about it? :)
Just as an FYI, the "shortest" solution I could come up with in ~10 minutes was 290 chars python3.
the difficulty is not about code complexity but mainly comes from problem comprehension ... everyone know classic Tic Tac Toe

I see you changed two of the validators but I don't think any of the public tests require columns.  That will be frustrating for people if the pass all the tests and fail two validators if they don't check columns.
:) I like it.  It knocked my size down to 164 and I think I could do it in under 15.   Approved.
Thanks!

I changed it so only lines of length N count for winning. This reduces the number of diagonals down to only 2, and you only have to check full rows and columns without checking smaller lengths, which I think is okay for Clash.
